item.title: Setting up startup infrastructure
item.description: I am currently starting my next phase of professional life involving being a CTO as a Service for two startups, initially. One thing than any company needs is basic IT infrastructure. Based on my experiences the last 7 years in LetsBuild and talking to various other people in my network, the following systems form the cornerstone of the companies Google Workspace - Email, Calendar When setting up mail, it’s important to setup SPF, DKIM and DMARC to avoid that the mail lands in receiver’s spam.

item.title: Setting up my own blog
item.description: I like statically generated web-sites. Using them skips a lot of heavy infrastructure and potential trouble securing that. So unless you need a large largely non technical marketing department running your website, and you are a little tech savy (which I should be in my job, good to keep in touch with the base). So I tried a few things, first Jekyll which supposedly is the major one out there, but it runs on ruby and ruby is a complex beast to install and maintain in different versions (probably not first time, but when you come back later, you can spend a lot of time just getting it right; a bit similar with Python.
